GraphicsLab

Class GraphicsLab

  • java.lang.Object
    • GraphicsLab.GraphicsLab
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    MainScene

    public abstract class GraphicsLab
extends java.lang.Object
    Defines the base class for Dan Cornford's Computer Graphics labs

    Encapsulates basic functionality that should be separated from the teaching goals of the individual labs, including creating and maintaining the application window, the application control loop, the use of axis aligned views, and the loading of textures.

    Adapted from Mark Bernard's LWJGL NeHe samples

    Author:
    Anthony Jones and Dan Cornford

      • run

        public final void run(int viewingMode,
                      java.lang.String windowTitle,
                      float animationScale)
        Runs the deriving lab sample by handing runtime control over to GraphicsLab's application loop
        Parameters:
        viewingMode - How the sample should be viewed - full screen, or in a window
        windowTitle - The title for the sample's application instance and window
        animationScale - A value that should be used to correctly scale animations across different machines. 1.0 corresponds to animations running at full speed, 0.5 at half speed, and so on

      • init

        private void init()
           throws java.lang.Exception
        Creates application resources and sets some initial OpenGL states *
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - -

      • createWindow

        private void createWindow()
                   throws java.lang.Exception
        Creates a windowed or full screen display for this sample
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - -

      • checkInput

        private void checkInput()
        Checks for user input corresponding to terminating the application and controlling the axis aligned views

      • updateCamera

        private void updateCamera()
        Updates the 'virtual camera'. Appropriate values are set for the axis aligned views if they are active; otherwise, the sample's viewpoint and projection settings are used

      • setSceneCamera

        protected void setSceneCamera()
        Sets default values for the sample's viewpoint and projection settings. This behaviour may be overriden by each sample to provide customised camera control; alternatively, deriving classes may call super.setSceneCamera and then provide custom camera position and orientation

      • renderFrame

        private void renderFrame()
        Renders a single frame to the application's display. If an axis aligned view is in use, appropriate axis lines will also be drawn

      • drawAxisLines

        protected void drawAxisLines()
        Draws the X,Y and Z axis lines for axis aligned views

      • cleanup

        private void cleanup()
        Allows the application to perform any last-minute operations before it is destroyed

      • loadTexture

        protected final org.newdawn.slick.opengl.Texture loadTexture(java.lang.String path)
                                                      throws java.lang.Exception
        Loads a texture from a given image file. Note: when using this function, prefer to use square textures whose width and height are both a power of 2; otherwise, your graphics card may not support the texture, or it may affect the performance of your animated scenes

        Texture loading code adapted from LWJGL documentation of the Slick-util library

        Parameters:
        path - The absolute or relative path of the image file to load as a texture
        Returns:
        A Texture object
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - - exception

      • loadTexture

        protected final org.newdawn.slick.opengl.Texture loadTexture(java.lang.String path,
                                                             java.lang.String imageType)
                                                      throws java.lang.Exception
        Loads a texture from a given image file. Note: when using this function, prefer to use square textures whose width and height are both a power of 2; otherwise, your graphics card may not support the texture, or it may affect the performance of your animated scenes

        Texture loading code adapted from LWJGL documentation of the Slick-util library

        Parameters:
        path - The absolute or relative path of the image file to load as a texture
        imageType - The type of image, e.g. "BMP", "JPG", "PNG"
        Returns:
        A Texture object
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - - exception
